stories.headline: Civil trial for ex-police officer set for 2026
stories.summary: A civil trial is scheduled in October 2026 for former Grand Rapids police officer Christopher Schurr, who is being sued by the family of Patrick Lyoya. Schurr will not be retried for murder in a fatal 2022 shooting, but the upcoming trial will address related civil claims. The case has involved extensive testimony and legal proceedings.

stories.headline: Jackson County makes short-term rentals cheaper for World Cup
stories.summary: Jackson County has approved an ordinance to ease restrictions and lower costs on short-term rentals for the 2026 World Cup. This measure aims to accommodate thousands of tourists by allowing certain residential properties to be rented short-term, filling the gap in available travel housing. The ordinance encourages more housing availability for important events like the World Cup, which will bring an estimated 650,000 people to Kansas City during the global soccer championship.

stories.headline: KC groups fighting hunger warn against cutting SNAP benefits
stories.summary: Community groups in Kansas City warn that proposed cuts to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) under the Trump administration could increase food insecurity, which currently affects around 112,000 Jackson County residents. Advocates say cuts could undermine the work done by local initiatives like the Nourish KC Community Kitchen, which serves 500 meals daily. The community groups emphasize the urgent need to support food assistance programs.

stories.headline: Iran fires missiles at US base in Qatar in retaliation
stories.summary: Iran launched a military attack on a US base in Qatar with ballistic missiles, in retaliation for US strikes on Iranian nuclear sites. Three Iranian officials said the attack was pre-emptive to reduce Iranian casualties and was coordinated to minimize escalation. The attack caused disruptions but no casualties. This escalation is part of the Iran-Israel conflict.

stories.headline: Feds want to imprison KC teen for ‘decades’ for Tesla fire
stories.summary: Feds are seeking a long prison sentence for Owen McIntire, a 19-year-old college student accused of torching two Tesla Cybertrucks in Kansas City. The fire did not cause any injuries but resulted in property damage. McIntire faces multiple charges including arson and unlawful possession of an unregistered destructive device. Authorities have elevated the case to the Department of Justice's national security division, highlighting the serious nature of the offense.
people: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives

stories.headline: Detainee would rather return to Venezuela than remain in harsh conditions at Krome
stories.summary: Nerwys Alexandro Reyes Pineda, detained at the Krome detention center, prefers returning to Venezuela over staying in the harsh conditions in U.S. immigration detention. He describes treatment of detainees as shackled and dehumanizing. Despite fears for his safety if returned, the inhumane environment and restrictions such as lack of basic clothing have pushed his desire to leave. He was released after an asylum claim was dismissed and arrested again during a routine immigration appointment.

stories.headline: Iran fires missiles at U.S. base in Qatar
stories.summary: Iran launched a military attack on a U.S. base in Qatar, targeting one of the largest American military installations in the Middle East, retaliating for U.S. strikes on critical Iranian nuclear sites. Qatar and the United States intercepted the missiles with no reported casualties. The attack has increased tensions in the region, with fears of further escalation as Iran looks for an off-ramp. The U.S. and allies are on alert following these events.

stories.headline: ‘Life just changed’: How South Florida doctors use tech to treat patients
stories.summary: Technology is driving future healthcare innovations in South Florida, including the use of simulators for training and high-intensity ultrasounds to treat cancer patients. These advancements assist in treating difficult conditions such as cancer, strokes, and genetic diseases, improving patients' quality of life. Dr. Omar Llaguna, a surgical oncologist at Memorial Healthcare System, demonstrates new tech aimed at destroying tumor cells and enhancing immune responses.

stories.headline: Need a ride at the Miami airport? A self-flying air taxi might be coming
stories.summary: The Miami-Dade Aviation Department and Wisk Aero are collaborating to introduce all-electric self-flying air taxis at Miami airport within a few years. These autonomous flying taxis will provide a new mode of transportation, similar to Uber or family rides, with the ability to land and take off vertically like helicopters but flying planes to South Florida. This innovative service aims to ease travel for residents and visitors alike by offering efficient and futuristic transit options.
